article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NerdWallet. Most retirees regret not saving more. A 2018 study by Transamerica Center for Retirement Studies found 73% wish theyâd put aside more money on a consistent basis, and half felt they waited too long to get serious about retirement saving. But retirement is about more than the balance in your 401(k).Â Even people with sizable nest eggs can wishÂ they handled certain aspects of retirement differently. Hoping to learn from othersâ mistakes, I asked advisers with the Financial Planning Association and the Alliance of Comprehensive Planners to share their clientsâ biggest regrets about retirement. Thirty-one advisers responded, and their answers revealed some common themes. Among them:âI wish we had traveled more while we couldâ All too often, health issues derail peopleâs travel plans, says certified financial planner Serina Shyu of Atlanta. They donât get around to taking that dream trip or get to see as many places as theyâd hoped. Even homebodies regret missed chances to see loved ones. âAnother version is where the health issue isnât [the retireeâs]. âI wish we had gone to see so-and-so,ââ says CFP Daniel B. Moisand of Melbourne, Florida. âSometimes we wait to reconnect with friends or family and that person dies or suffers a stroke or dementia.â Financial plannersÂ can help people get clarity about how much money they can safely spend in retirement. CFP Linda Y. Leitz of Colorado Springs, Colorado, says sheâs been able to reassure several clients so they could get started on their bucket lists. âAs they aged and either had health concerns or just didnât enjoy being away from home as much, they all were really glad that they traveled,â Leitz says. âThey donât mind cutting back in later years because they had done the things that were important to them, early in retirement, while they could enjoy them.ââI wish Iâd had something to retire toâ People can be so tired of working, or sick of their particular job, that theyÂ retireÂ at the first opportunity without thinking through how they will spend their time. Many struggle to replace the structure, meaning and purpose their work provided. Also on MarketWatch: Retiree warning: History suggests weâre overdue for a bear market âThey look back five or six years after they have retired to realize the time has flown by and they have not done anything,â says CFP Jonathan P. Bednar of Knoxville, Tennessee. CFP Jennifer Weber of Lake Success, New York, counsels her clients to think about âhow to spend their days with meaning.â That could mean a part-time job, consulting gigs, volunteering or spending more time with friends and family, she says.âI wish I had more friendsâ Something else work provides: social contact. People often donât realize how much social interaction their workplace provides, says CFP Patti B. Black of Birmingham, Alabama. Black recommends volunteer groups, clubs and classes as potential sources of new friends. âPeople may feel âout of the loopâ in retirement,â Black says. âIt takes time and effort to find a new tribe.ââI wish we hadnât bought that houseâ CFP Kevin M. OâBrien of Northborough, Massachusetts, says some of his clientsâ retirement home purchases triggered serious buyerâs remorse. The clients hadnât spent enough time in the community before buying, and now wish they lived somewhere else. The cost and stress of changing homes is usually significant. Although moving may be the right choice, no one should buy a retirement home in haste, OâBrien says. See: The No. 1 thing people with fat savings accounts scrimp on that you likely donât âRetirees should rent in areas theyâre interested in retiring to before making a major purchase,â OâBrien says.âI wish weâd talked about our expectations for retirementâ Itâs not uncommon for spouses to have dramatically different visions of retirement. OâBrien has advised couples where one spouse was thrilled to be the grandkidsâ child care provider while the other longed to travel and be more spontaneous. âThey canât just up and go because they are relied on to watch the grandchildren,â OâBrien says. Different expectations can cause serious ruptures in relationships, and they may be among the reasons why divorce rates for people 55 and older have more than doubled since 1990 even as the overall divorce rate subsides, Black says. Black urges spouses to discuss how they will spend their time, including how the division of household chores might change and even whether theyâll have lunch together every day. As with so many other aspects of marriage, the willingness to talk through disagreements and find compromises is essential, she says. âRetirement is a major life transition, and you have to be patient with yourself and your spouse,â Black says.More from NerdWallet: 4 Things to Know if Youâve Never Budgeted Before Donât Shop This Way in 2020 Equifax Breach: Claims Cutoff and More Scammers Ahead Liz Weston is a writer at NerdWallet.
